dt: {bc}an act or circumstance that intensifies something or makes something worse

dt.t: His interference was an {wi}aggravation{/wi} of the situation.

dt: {bc}the act, action, or result of {d_link|aggravating|aggravate} something or someone

dt.t: Her job involves a lot of stress and {wi}aggravation{/wi}.

pt: Although {it}aggravate{/it} has been used to refer to rousing someone to anger since the 17th century, it has been the object of disapproval only since about 1870. It is used in expository prose

pt.t: when his silly conceit … about his not-very-good early work has begun to {it}aggravate{/it} us

pt: but seems to be more common in speech and casual writing.

pt.t: a good profession for him, because bus drivers get {it}aggravated{/it}
& now this letter comes to {it}aggravate{/it} me a thousand times worse

pt: The "make worse" meaning is far more common in published prose than the "rouse to anger" meaning. Such is not the case, however, with {it}aggravation{/it} and {it}aggravating. Aggravation{/it} is used in the "irritation, provocation" sense somewhat more than in its earlier senses; {it}aggravating{/it} has practically no use other than to express annoyance.

et: borrowed from Late Latin {it}aggravātiōn-, aggravātiō{/it} "a weighing down," from Latin {it}aggravāre{/it} "to weigh down, {et_link|aggravate|aggravate}" + {it}-tiōn-, -tiō,{/it} suffix of action nouns
shortdef: an act or circumstance that intensifies something or makes something worse
the act, action, or result of aggravating something or someone; especially : an increasing in seriousness or severity
